thread.title: Woodside makes takeover bid for PNG-focused explorer Oil Search
thread.title_full: Woodside makes takeover bid for PNG-focused explorer Oil Search | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Michael Roddan
title: Woodside makes takeover bid for PNG-focused explorer Oil Search
text:
CASHED-up energy giant Woodside Petroleum has made a takeover bid for PNG-focused explorer Oil Search, offering to acquire all the shares in the company.
Woodside is offering one share for every four Oil Search securities in a non-binding proposal.
The Papua New Guinea government owns a 10 per cent stake in Oil Search.
Oil Search has a market valuation of $10.2 billion, according to its stock’s closing price yesterday, compared with Woodside's market capitalisation of $25.2 billion.
In a statement, Woodside said the proposal was “consistent with Woodside’s strategy of delivering superior shareholder returns by maximising the value of our core assets, leveraging our capabilities and growing our portfolio”.
Oil Search has made considerable progress in a major liquefied natural gas project in PNG over the past few years, which will extract 6.9 million tonnes of LNG each year sourced from seven fields.
The gas is transported by pipeline to an LNG processing plant south of the Papua New Guinea capital, Port Moresby before being loaded onto tankers bound for Asian markets.
Production started in April last year before reaching final completion in February this year.
Woodside has been actively seeking acquisitions for some time and was considered ever eager to tie up future growth streams after a proposed $US2.5 billion deal to buy into the Leviathan gas venture off Israel fell through last year.
Woodside and Oil Search shares headed in different directions upon exiting trading halts shortly after 11am.
Oil Search rocketed 14 per cent to $7.66, trickling above the implied offer price of $7.65, while Woodside shed 4 per cent to $29.35.
 Woodside makes takeover offer for Oil Search
